page.title: 03LOCAL HISTORY OF BALFRON
page.content: Roman Road is another aptly named road as it leads to the site of a {Roman fort}which is visible nowadays as a tree covered mound. In Mediaeval times, a{"Motte and Bailey" castle}was built where the Roman fort had been. Dunkeld Court and Burns-Begg Crescent are both recently named streets, the former being after {Lt.Col. John Dunkeld,}a local councillor for many years, and the latter after the{Rev. Burns-Begg,}who was minister in the North Church for many years and was a descendant of the famous poet Robert Burns. A{single track railway}ran through the area on its way along the Blane Valley. Passenger trains were used to bring holiday-makers into the area, while farmers had their milk transported more quickly into the town (last passenger train in 1934).
